question_original: My baby weight is 452 gram in 22weeks..is this normal
question_translated: My baby weighs 452 grams at 22 weeks...is this normal?
answer:
Yes, this is normal. Your baby is growing well. Keep eating nutritious food and taking your iron and folic acid tablets as advised.

1.  We will measure your weight and blood pressure and will look for any signs of de Ô¨Å ciencies or disorders
2.  As your baby is gaining weight, you should include energy dense food items like cereals (wheat, rice, jowar, ragi, bajra), pulses (green gram, 
Bengal gram, soyabean), milk and milk products, cooking oils (mustard oil, soyabean oil, groundnut oil, coconut oil), nuts and oilseeds (sesame 
seeds, groundnuts, flax seeds) and jaggery. Ensure that you eat at least 3 main meals and 2 nutritious snacks to meet increased nutrient 
requirements and proper growth and development of the baby

question_original: Sometimes I don‚Äôt feel the baby‚Äôs move ..is it okay or something else?
question_translated: Sometimes I do not feel fetal movements. Is this normal or is there a concern?
answer:
1. Answer ONLY using the provided context. Do not speculate or generate information not found in the retrieved data. If the provided context doesn't fully answer the question, state the limitations. Example: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have enough information to answer that accurately.‚Äù
2. Be reassuring but honest. Do not minimize legitimate concerns. If the topic is serious, clearly explain when to seek medical help.
3. Use clear, non-technical language. Avoid jargon and explain complex terms simply.
4. Warning signs: When discussing symptoms or warning signs, clearly distinguish between normal variations and symptoms that require medical attention. List these separately if appropriate.
5. If you detect any signs of a possible emergency (such as heavy bleeding, severe pain, loss of consciousness, seizures, absent fetal movement, severe swelling, difficulty breathing, fever with rash, premature rupture of membranes, or vision changes):
Do NOT give any advice.
Respond ONLY with:
"IMPORTANT: This appears to be an emergency situation that requires immediate medical attention.

This chatbot cannot provide emergency medical advice. Please:
1. Contact your healthcare provider immediately OR
2. Go to the nearest emergency department OR
3. Call your local emergency number for immediate assistance.

Do not wait or delay seeking professional care.‚Äù
6. Do not provide: Any specific drug brand or prescription recommendations; Any information related to fetal gender detection or selection; Any instructions or advice for suicidal/self-harm situations. Instead, respond only with the relevant crisis hotline (India: 9152987821, US: 988, UK: 0800 689 5652).
7. Do not answer off topic questions, ie: questions which are not related to  pregnancy, postpartum, or maternal/newborn wellness at all. (if off-topic, say: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry, I can only help with pregnancy and maternal-health questions.‚Äù),
8. Respond in the same language as the original question, if the language is hindi written in english, do the same.

sources.content:
‚Ä¢ Have 8 hours of sleep at night and at least 2 hours rest during the day.
‚Ä¢ Lie on your left side as it increases the blood supply to the foetus.
‚Ä¢ Avoid hard work such as lifting heavy weight.
‚Ä¢ Do not overexert yourself and delegate few tasks to others.

question_original: I have seen prickly heat and itching on some part of my body... What should I do?
question_translated: I have observed miliaria and pruritus on some area of my body... What should I do?
answer:
‚Ä¢  Wash the affected part with soap and cooled, boiled water 3 to 4 times each day, 
gently soaking off the crusts.
‚Ä¢  After each washing, paint the sores with gentian violet (p. 370) or spread on an 
antibiotic cr
eam containing bacitracin such as Polysporin (p. 370).
‚Ä¢  If the infection is spread over a large area or causes fever
, give penicillin tablets 
(p. 350) or dicloxacillin (p. 350). If the person is allergic to penicillin, or if these 
medicines do not seem to be helping, give erythromycin (p. 354), doxycycline 
(p. 355), or cotrimoxazole (p. 357)

‚Ä¢ abnormal lumps or masses
‚Ä¢ unusual thinning or loss of hair, or

question_original: Bacche ko Tej Sardi ho to kaise usko maintain Karen
question_translated: How to maintain a child with severe cold?
answer:
1. The Comfort of the Sick Person
A person who is sick should 
rest in a quiet, comfortable place 
with plenty of fresh air and light. He 
should keep from getting too hot or 
cold. If the air is cold or the person 
is chilled, cover him with a sheet or 
blanket. But if the weather is hot or 
the person has a fever, do not cover 
him at all (see p. 75).
2. Liquids
In nearly every sickness, especially when there is 
fever or diarrhea, the sick person should drink plenty 
of liquids: water, tea, juices, broths, etc.

It gets worse after wearing jeans. Could it be because 
of allergy or because they are tight?
Q19 
Light cotton clothing should be used to prevent overheating in a child with 
fever. Do not bundle up the febrile child with heavy blankets or too many 
warm clothes, as they may impair heat loss from the body. What kind of clothing should be worn by 
children when they have fever? Q20 
Ch-003.indd   14 08-09-2021   10:07:12

If she is crying and seems unhappy, 
give her acetaminophen (paracetamol) or ibuprofen in 
the right dosage (see p. 379), and give her lots of liquids. If she is very hot and shaky
, wet her with cool (not cold) 
water and fan her. Malnutrition may cause many different problems in children, including:

‚Ä¢ Keep the baby warm.
‚Ä¢ Ensure care of the umbilicus, skin and eyes.
‚Ä¢ Ensure good suckling while breastfeeding. 
‚Ä¢ Screen the newborn for danger signs.
‚Ä¢ Advise the mother and family members on immunisation.

sources.content:
WARNING: Do not give any kind of antibiotic or injections to a child with a simple 
cold. They will not help and may cause harm. Sometimes signs of cold are caused 
by the polio virus, and giving the child an injection could bring on paralysis from 
polio (see p. 314).

question_original: 2.5 months hogae h pregnancy ko but vomet ya kch ni hora mjhe
question_translated: Query: I am 2.5 months pregnant but I am not experiencing any vomiting or other symptoms.
answer:
1.  We will measure your weight and blood pressure and will look for any signs of de Ô¨Å ciencies or disorders
2.  Hope your nausea and vomiting are subsiding. Ensure that you eat 3 main meals and 1 nutritious snack
3.  As your baby's bones are hardening and teeth have also begun to form, remember to include calcium rich foods such as milk, curd, paneer, 
ragi, sesame seeds, bathua leaves, methi leaves, etc., in your diet
4.  Continue consuming one Folic Acid tablet (400 mg) daily and dietary sources of folate such as catla Ô¨Å sh, moth beans, kidney beans, soybean, 
spinach, sem ki phali, sarson ka saag, chicken liver which are important for the normal development of your baby's brain and spinal cord

5. No pulling of  the baby 
6. No routine episiotomy
7. No fundal pressure
8.  No immediate cord

question_original: I am 33‚ÄØweeks pregnant and suddenly gushing bright‚Äëred blood with sharp cramps.
question_translated: I am 33 weeks pregnant and suddenly experiencing bright-red blood gushing with sharp cramps.
answer:
This is a serious condition. You should go to the hospital immediately. You may need an emergency caesarean section. If you cannot reach a healthcare provider, go to the emergency room. Be sure to tell them you are pregnant or were pregnant within the last year.
This list of urgent maternal warning signs was developed by the Council on Patient Safety in Women‚Äôs Health Care.
Headache that won‚Äôt go away or gets worse over time
Dizziness or fainting
Changes in your vision
Fever of 100.4¬∞F or higher
Extreme swelling of your hands or face
Thoughts of harming yourself or your baby
Trouble breathing
Chest pain or fast beating heart
Severe nausea and throwing up
Severe belly pain that doesn‚Äôt go away
Baby‚Äôs movement stopping or slowing during pregnancy
Severe swelling, redness or pain of your leg or arm
Vaginal bleeding or fluid leaking during pregnancy
Heavy vaginal bleeding or discharge after pregnancy
Overwhelming tiredness
Learn more at cdc.gov/HearHer

question_original: Is it safe to take‚ÄØ500‚ÄØmg amoxicillin three times a day for my UTI?
question_translated: Is it safe to take 500 mg of amoxicillin three times a day for my urinary tract infection (UTI)?
answer:
Amoxicillin is a good choice for treating urinary tract infections (UTIs). It is a 
penicillin antibiotic that is effective against many bacteria that cause UTIs. It is 
also safe to take for a UTI. Amoxicillin is available in 250 mg and 500 mg tablets. 
The usual dose for a UTI is 500 mg three times a day for 3 to 7 days. It is 
important to take the entire course of antibiotics to ensure that the infection is 
completely gone. If you have any questions or concerns, please talk to your 
doctor.

metadata.title: IAP Parent Guideline

question_original: I‚Äôm feeling constant chest pain and can barely catch my breath at 29‚ÄØweeks.
question_translated: I am experiencing persistent chest pain and have difficulty breathing at 29 weeks of pregnancy.
answer:
Hello, I‚Äôm sorry to hear that you‚Äôre experiencing chest pain and difficulty breathing. This can be concerning, especially during pregnancy. It‚Äôs important to seek medical attention as soon as possible to ensure the safety of both you and your baby. Some possible causes of chest pain and difficulty breathing during pregnancy include:

Preeclampsia: This is a condition that can develop during pregnancy and is characterized by high blood pressure and protein in the urine. It can cause chest pain and difficulty breathing, among other symptoms. If you have preeclampsia, you may need to be monitored closely or receive medication to lower your blood pressure.

Heart problems: Pregnancy can put extra strain on the heart, and some women may develop heart problems during pregnancy. This can cause chest pain and difficulty breathing. If you have a history of heart problems, it‚Äôs important to let your healthcare provider know.

Pneumonia: This is an infection of the lungs that can cause chest pain and difficulty breathing. It‚Äôs more common in pregnant women who are smokers or have other underlying health conditions.

Asthma: If you have asthma, it‚Äôs important to keep it under control during pregnancy. Pregnancy can make asthma symptoms worse, and you may need to adjust your medication or treatment plan.

It‚Äôs important to note that chest pain and difficulty breathing can also be caused by other conditions, such as anxiety or panic attacks. If you‚Äôre experiencing these symptoms, it‚Äôs important to seek medical attention to rule out any serious underlying causes. Your healthcare provider can help determine the cause of your symptoms and provide appropriate treatment.

In the meantime, here are some things you can do to help manage your symptoms:

Rest: Try to rest and take it easy. This can help reduce the strain on your heart and lungs.

Drink plenty of fluids: Staying hydrated can help reduce the risk of dehydration, which can make symptoms worse.

Use a fan or air conditioner: This can help keep you cool and reduce the risk of overheating, which can make symptoms worse.

Avoid triggers: If you have asthma, try to avoid triggers such as smoke, dust, or pollen. If you have preeclampsia, avoid strenuous activity and limit your salt intake.

Take your medication as prescribed: If you‚Äôre taking medication for a condition such as asthma or preeclampsia, be sure to take it as prescribed.
